title.narrative: BBC Media Action Climate Change Adaptation 2018-2019

description.narrative: The overall goal of this project is contribute to that more rural Cambodians living in vulnerable flood/drought-prone provinces are trying new adaptation practices or techniques that have been adapted for challenging weather conditions.

Den 2 juni 2017 inkom BBC Media Action med en ansökan om finansiering av ett klimatanpassningsprogram, "Neighbours Together". En reviderad version av ansökan inlämnades den 20 oktober 2017.
Syftet med insatsen är att förse lokalbefolkning med kunskap om effektiva metoder för att minska negativa konsekvenser av dessa katastrofer och därigenom bistå lokala samhällen i att stärka sin motståndskraft mot översvämningar, torka och andra klimatrelaterade katastrofer. Insatsen utgår från forskning kring klimatets effekter på gräsrotsnivån samt effektiva åtgärder för att förebygga negativa effekter av naturkatastrofer. Särskilt fokus görs på särskilt utsatta grupper samt kvinnor. Insatsen genomförs av BBC Media Action i samverkan med tv-stationer och civilsamhällesorganisationer genom tv-media, social media och mobila informationstillfällen.
Insatsens totala belopp uppgår till 10 MSEK, utav vilket Sida ombeds bidra med hela beloppet.
The support aim at contributing to improved capacity on the local level for climate change adaption in Cambodia.

description.narrative: The concluding assessment will summarise lessons learned from the project period. Assessments on narrative and financial reports have been made under respective years 2018 and 2019, the conditions in the General Conditions annexed to agreement have been fulfilled. The list of assets was received 9 October after request. The audit covering the entire project 2018-2019 period has been assessed and approved on 20191014. The accrued interest of 717.73 US$ and remaining funds of 217.07 US$ were repaid on 20191128. The project has achieved the results it set out to achieve, and BBC Media Action has its strengths in conveying messages and using media for reaching out. At the onset, a large scale study of people's everyday experience of climate change was conducted, reaching 1,660 individuals in 163 villages across 22 provinces. The findings allowed BBC Media Action to be informed of both the topics to be covered and the format of a TV programme in ordes to ensure the content would be accessible, engaging and transformative for the target audience. Below a summary of the achieved results:-12 TV episodes (30 minutes each) aired on CTN and MyTV from Feb May 2019, prior to this was a launch 12 February 2019-2 types of toolkit materials developed (communication guide and TV content for outreach)-48 NGOs practitioners from 33 NGOs partners working on climate adaptation initiatives trained-marketing materials produced-6 outreach events conducted (6 screenings and discussion groups in 3 locations) The number of episodes were reduced with two very early on and focussing on the on-line reach. The assessment is that this was a good decision can considering that the overall reach was over 4 million in total (all channels), and 1.5 million views of content on Facebook. The lessons learned by BBC Media Action from the project are:-Allocate adequate time for format development-Showcase the economic benefits of taking action-The audience liked the technical animations but would like them to be easier to follow-Future programmes should continue to think beyond vulnerabilities as regards climate change-Viewers want to know what happened next The BBC Media Action in Phnom Penh uses the financial systems of the BBC London office. The knowledge of how the central BBC financial follow-up system works, the implications of the same, is low at the local office in Phnom Penh. This has caused serious delays for the budgeting and planning, and resulted in unnecessary misunderstandings and time spent to understand availability of remaining funds. Addding to this, the rather big staff turnover at the Phnom Penh office has caused further complications. The involvement of the controller function at the embassy has been invaluable in the process.
